name: Aluminum
fact: Once more valuable than gold, aluminium became cheap after the 1886 Hall-Heroult process unlocked mass production for packaging, aircraft and power cables.

name: Barley
fact: One of humanity's earliest domesticated grains; prized for malt in beer and whisky, and still widely grown as hardy animal feed in cool climates.

name: Beef
fact: Cattle prices follow a multi-year 'cattle cycle'; droughts shrink herds, then later tight supplies can push beef prices sharply higher.

name: Bitumen
fact: Natural asphalt was used in ancient Mesopotamia for waterproofing boats and buildings; today it is the binder that makes modern road surfaces stick together.

name: Brent
fact: Named after a North Sea oil field; Brent became a global benchmark and influences pricing for a large share of internationally traded crude oils.

name: Butter
fact: Butter prices often swing with milkfat supply; European intervention stocks and seasonal dairy output have historically smoothed, then sometimes amplified, market moves.

name: Canola
fact: Canola was bred in Canada in the 1970s from rapeseed to reduce erucic acid; it became a major edible oil and biodiesel feedstock worldwide.

name: Cheese
fact: Cheese trading tracks milk solids; US Class III milk futures are closely linked because much of that milk is ultimately turned into cheese.

name: Coal
fact: Coal powered the Industrial Revolution; even today it remains vital for steelmaking as metallurgical coal, despite declining use in some power grids.

name: Cobalt
fact: Cobalt coloured glass and ceramics deep blue for centuries; now it is a key lithium-ion battery ingredient, with supply heavily concentrated in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

name: Cocoa
fact: Cocoa beans were once used as currency by the Aztecs; modern supply is dominated by West Africa, so weather and disease there can ripple through chocolate prices.

name: Coffee
fact: Legend credits an Ethiopian goatherd, Kaldi, with coffee's discovery; coffeehouses later became hubs of politics and science across Europe and the Middle East.

name: Copper
fact: Copper is among the first metals worked by humans; its superb conductivity makes it indispensable for wiring, and traders call it 'Dr Copper' for its economic signalling.

name: Corn
fact: Corn underpins food, feed and fuel; in the US a large share becomes ethanol, so energy policy and petrol demand can directly affect grain prices.

name: Cotton
fact: Cotton fuelled the Industrial Revolution's textile boom; today it remains a major natural fibre, with prices sensitive to weather, pests and global apparel demand.

name: Crude Oil
fact: Crude oil futures transformed energy hedging; WTI delivery at Cushing, Oklahoma made a storage hub into one of the world's most watched pricing points.

name: Di-ammonium
fact: Di-ammonium phosphate (DAP) supplies both nitrogen and phosphorus; prices often move with natural-gas-driven ammonia costs and phosphate rock availability.

name: Eggs (China)
fact: Egg prices can be surprisingly jumpy; feed costs, transport constraints and disease outbreaks can quickly tighten supply for a product with a very short shelf life.

name: Eggs (US)
fact: US egg prices are famously volatile; avian influenza outbreaks and hen-housing regulations can abruptly reduce supply, sending wholesale prices soaring for months.

name: Ethanol
fact: Ethanol is a biofuel blended into most US petrol; Henry Ford designed the Model T to run on alcohol fuels, long before modern blending mandates.

name: Feeder Cattle
fact: Feeder cattle futures help ranchers and feedlots manage risk between weaning and finishing; grain prices matter because feed is a major cost driver.

name: Gallium
fact: Gallium melts in your hand at about 30C; it is crucial for LEDs and high-power electronics made from gallium arsenide and gallium nitride.

name: Gasoline
fact: Modern gasoline blends are tightly specified for emissions; seasonal 'summer' and 'winter' formulations can create recurring price patterns around refinery changeovers.

name: Germanium
fact: Germanium helped power early transistors before silicon took over; it is still valuable for fibre-optic cables and infrared optics used in night-vision systems.

name: Gold
fact: Gold has served as money, jewellery and a safe haven; all the gold ever mined would fit into a surprisingly small cube, roughly the size of a large building.

name: Heating Oil
fact: Heating oil is essentially diesel-like distillate; cold winters can spike demand, and its futures are often used as a proxy hedge for diesel exposure.

name: HRC Steel
fact: Hot-rolled coil is a benchmark for flat steel used in cars and appliances; prices track construction and manufacturing cycles, making it a bellwether for industry.

name: Indium
fact: Indium is scarce and mostly recovered as a by-product of zinc; it enables indium-tin-oxide coatings that make touchscreens and flat displays work.

name: Iron Ore
fact: Iron ore is the backbone of steel; seaborne trade is dominated by Australia and Brazil, while Chinese blast furnaces set much of global demand.

name: Iron Ore (CNY)
fact: China's iron ore futures have become an important price signal; mainland trading can influence sentiment even for seaborne ore priced in US dollars.

name: Kraft Pulp
fact: The kraft process, invented in the 1880s, makes strong paper fibres; demand for packaging and e-commerce boxes has made pulp a surprisingly modern commodity.

name: Lead
fact: Lead's Latin name, plumbum, gave us 'plumbing'; today most lead goes into lead-acid batteries, and it is among the most recycled metals on Earth.

name: Lean Hogs
fact: Lean hogs futures replaced live hogs in the late 1990s; cash settlement better reflects modern pork production and reduces delivery logistics problems.

name: Lithium
fact: Lithium-ion batteries were commercialised in 1991; lithium demand surged with electronics and EVs, earning it the nickname 'white gold' in some mining regions.

name: Live Cattle
fact: Live cattle prices are shaped by pasture conditions and feed costs; the multi-year herd cycle means supply can lag demand, amplifying price swings.

name: Lumber
fact: Lumber futures became headline news during the 2020-2021 housing boom; sawmill capacity and building starts can move prices dramatically in short periods.

name: Magnesium
fact: Magnesium is the lightest structural metal; alloying it with aluminium cuts weight in vehicles, and it also burns with an intense white flare in pyrotechnics.

name: Manganese
fact: Manganese is essential for making most steels tougher; it is also a key ingredient in some modern battery chemistries, linking steel and EV supply chains.

name: Methanol
fact: Methanol was once made by distilling wood, hence 'wood alcohol'; today it is a major chemical feedstock and can even be used as a marine fuel.

name: Milk
fact: Milk is quoted in hundredweight in US markets; Class III milk relates to cheese production, so dairy prices often move with cheese and whey demand.

name: Molybdenum
fact: Molybdenum strengthens steel and improves corrosion resistance; its main ore, molybdenite, was once mistaken for lead ore by early miners.

name: Naphtha
fact: Naphtha is a refinery stream prized by petrochemical plants; it is cracked into building blocks like ethylene, linking crude oil and plastics markets.

name: Natural Gas
fact: US natural gas pricing centres on the Henry Hub; gas is measured in MMBtu and is crucial for heating, power generation and industrial fertiliser production.

name: Neodymium
fact: Neodymium enables powerful permanent magnets; these magnets are vital for wind turbines and EV motors, making this rare-earth metal strategically important.

name: Nickel
fact: Nickel is best known for stainless steel; it also boosts battery energy density, and a dramatic 2022 short squeeze highlighted how tight metal markets can become.

name: Oat
fact: Oats thrive in cool climates and are staples in porridge and feed; markets can react to Canadian harvests because Canada is a major exporter.

name: Orange Juice
fact: Frozen concentrated orange juice futures date to the 1960s; Florida freezes and Brazilian crop disease can rapidly change supply, making the contract notoriously weather-sensitive.

name: Palladium
fact: Palladium, discovered in 1803, is named after asteroid Pallas; it is crucial for petrol catalytic converters, so automotive demand strongly influences prices.

name: Palm Oil
fact: Palm oil is the world's highest-yield vegetable oil; it appears in countless foods and soaps, while sustainability concerns have made its supply chain politically charged.

name: Platinum
fact: Platinum is used in catalysts and jewellery; most production comes from South Africa, and new demand themes include hydrogen fuel cells and industrial catalysts.

name: Polyethylene
fact: Polyethylene, the most common plastic, was discovered by accident in 1933 at ICI; it now dominates packaging films, bottles and countless household products.

name: Polypropylene
fact: Polypropylene was developed in the 1950s; it is lightweight and tough, used in car parts, reusable containers and non-woven fabrics like medical masks.

name: Polyvinyl
fact: Polyvinyl chloride (PVC) became widespread in the 20th century; it is durable for pipes and cables, but its chlorine content makes recycling and additives a long-running controversy.

name: Potatoes
fact: Potatoes reached Europe in the 16th century and reshaped diets; dependence on a single variety contributed to the Irish famine, a stark lesson in crop diversity.

name: Poultry
fact: Chicken became a global staple thanks to modern breeding and feed efficiency; maize and soy prices matter because feed is the dominant cost for producers.

name: Propane
fact: Propane is liquefied petroleum gas stored under pressure; it heats homes, powers forklifts and feeds petrochemicals, so demand spans both winter weather and industry.

name: Rapeseed
fact: Rapeseed oil has long been used in Europe; modern varieties support biodiesel and edible oils, with prices sensitive to EU biofuel policy and harvest yields.

name: Rhodium
fact: Rhodium is one of the rarest precious metals; tiny supply and catalytic-converter demand can cause extreme price spikes, making it a poster child for thin markets.

name: Rice
fact: Rice feeds billions and is deeply tied to Asian food security; export bans and monsoon variability can quickly tighten global supply and move prices.

name: Rubber
fact: Natural rubber comes from Hevea trees; Charles Goodyear's 1839 vulcanisation breakthrough made tyres practical, permanently linking rubber prices to transport demand.

name: Salmon
fact: Norway pioneered industrial salmon farming; prices can swing with sea-lice outbreaks, feed costs and export demand, turning a fish into a globally traded commodity.

name: Silver
fact: Silver once backed currencies; photography demand faded, but industrial use is rising again because silver is highly conductive and important in solar panels.

name: Soda Ash
fact: Soda ash (sodium carbonate) is essential for glass and detergents; the 19th-century Solvay process revolutionised production and remains a landmark in industrial chemistry.

name: Soybeans
fact: Soybeans originated in East Asia and became a global protein and oil crop; trade policy can move prices because shipments are dominated by a few exporting giants.

name: Steel
fact: Steel's mass production took off with 19th-century processes like Bessemer; it remains the backbone of modern infrastructure, from bridges to ships to wind turbines.

name: Sugar
fact: Sugar helped drive colonial trade and politics; today Brazil's cane can become either sugar or ethanol, so energy prices and milling choices influence the sweetener market.

name: Sunflower Oil
fact: Sunflower was first domesticated in North America; modern production is concentrated around the Black Sea, so regional geopolitics and weather can influence global cooking-oil prices.

name: Tea
fact: Tea trade reshaped empires; events like the Boston Tea Party show its political history, while modern prices reflect auction markets and weather in key growing regions.

name: Tellurium
fact: Tellurium, named from Latin tellus, is rare; it is used in cadmium-telluride solar panels and thermoelectric devices, linking a niche metal to clean-energy tech.

name: Tin
fact: Tin enabled the Bronze Age when alloyed with copper; today it remains vital for solder in electronics, and it can suffer 'tin pest' brittleness in extreme cold.

name: Titanium
fact: Titanium is strong, light and corrosion-resistant; it is extracted from minerals like rutile and powers aircraft, medical implants and chemical processing equipment.

name: TTF Gas
fact: The Dutch TTF virtual hub became Europe's key gas benchmark; its prices can ripple through electricity markets because gas often sets the marginal power price.

name: UK Gas
fact: The UK's National Balancing Point is a virtual gas trading hub; it helped pioneer liberalised gas markets in the 1990s and influenced European trading models.

name: Uranium
fact: Uranium's energy density is immense; a small amount of fuel can power a reactor for years, and supply dynamics are shaped by mining, enrichment and long-term contracts.

name: Urea
fact: Urea was the first organic compound synthesised from inorganic precursors in 1828; today it is the most common nitrogen fertiliser, tying crop yields to natural-gas-based ammonia costs.

name: Wheat
fact: Wheat was domesticated in the Fertile Crescent; futures markets for wheat are among the oldest, and prices react quickly to drought, war and export restrictions.

name: Wool
fact: Wool's natural crimp traps air for insulation; Merino wool is prized for fine fibres, and Australia's clip has long influenced global textile markets.

name: Zinc
fact: Zinc is best known for galvanising steel to prevent rust; it also forms brass with copper and is an essential micronutrient in agriculture and human health.
